Where compartmentation is required, each compartment shall have an independent smoke control system. The system shall be automatically activated and capable of manual operation in accordance with Sections 907.2.18 and 907.2.19.
A fire alarm system shall be provided where required by Sections 907.2.18 and 907.2.19.
Means of egress shall be in accordance with Sections 405.7.1 and 405.7.2.

Each floor level shall be provided with not fewer than two exits. Where compartmentation is required by Section 405.4, each compartment shall have not fewer than one exit and not fewer than one exit access doorway into the adjoining compartment.

Every required stairway serving floor levels more than 30 feet (9144 mm) below the finished floor of its level of exit discharge shall comply with the requirements for a smokeproof enclosure as provided in Section 1023.12.

A standby power system complying with Section 2702 shall be provided for the standby power loads specified in Section 405.8.1. An emergency power system complying with Section 2702 shall be provided for the emergency power loads specified in Section 405.8.2.

The following are classified as standby power loads:
  1. Smoke control system.
  2. Ventilation and automatic fire detection equipment for smokeproof enclosures.
  3. Elevators, as required in Section 3003.

diagrams.title: Standby Power Systems
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
Standby and emergency standby power systems is an alternate source of power that is utilized to run critical systems when the primary power source fails. These are typically generators with an independent fuel source (diesel, gasoline, solar). Standby power systems are required to operate critical building systems, hazardous materials operations, and ventilation systems. Emergency standby power systems are required to operate life safety and fire alarm systems.

Standby power systems must automatically transfer on a power outage within 60 seconds, whereas emergency standby power systems must transfer within 10 seconds. Both of these systems are required to provide at least 2 hours of power. These systems must be UL 2200 listed, and be installed in accordance with IFC, NFPA 110, and NFPA 111. Section 2702.2 of the building code outlines specific occupancies and systems where these are required.

children.body:
The following are classified as emergency power loads:
  1. Emergency voice/alarm communications systems.
  2. Fire alarm systems.
  3. Automatic fire detection systems.
  4. Elevator car lighting.
  5. Means of egress and exit sign illumination as required by Chapter 10.
  6. Fire pumps.
The underground building shall be equipped throughout with a standpipe system in accordance with Section 905.

diagrams.title: Standpipe Types
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Standpipes, Types: - There are five types of standpipes - automatic dry, automatic wet, manual dry, manual wet, and semiautomatic dry. Automatic dry systems are pressurized with air, when a hose valve is opened, the air is released and the system fills with water. Automatic wet systems are filled with water at all times. Manual dry systems are not connected to a water supply, and must be supplied with water from the fire department. This is done via a fire department connection (FDC). Manual wet systems are filled with water, but require a supplemental fire department connection to meet required demand. Semiautomatic dry systems do not have water in them, but when a hose valve is opened, a remote switch opens the valve and allows water to fill the system.

diagrams.title: Standpipe System Classes
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
Standpipe Systems - There are three classification of standpipes:
  • Class I standpipes are equipped with a 2-1/2" hose connection and are intended for fire department use only.
  • Class II standpipes are equipped with a 1-1/2" hose and connection, and are intended primarily for building occupant use.
  • Class III standpipes are equipped with a 2-1/2" hose connection, reduced down to a 1-1/2" connected hose. These are intended for use by building occupants and fire department personnel.

diagrams.title: Open Parking Garage vs. Open Parking Structure requirements
diagrams.descriptionHtml: The main differences between an open parking garage and an open parking structure are that only an open parking garages have a min. clear height and are limited to construction types I, II, and IV. Both open garages and open parking structures require a lot of ventilation, in open parking structures the open wall area is based on area per linear foot while in open parking garage open wall area is based on a percent of wall area and perimeter length.

diagrams.title: Mechanical Protection - Ducts
diagrams.descriptionHtml: The mechanical code requires protection of ductwork installed in location that may be subject to vehicle or other impact by an approved barrier.

diagrams.title: Enclosed Parking Garage Ventilation - Ducted System
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Enclosed parking garages are required to have continuously running ventilation systems unless provided with approved sensor control system. Refer to the applicable mechanical code for automatic control requirements as the UMC and IMC automatic system control requirements are different.

diagrams.title: Enclosed Parking Garage Ventilation - Ductless Jet-Induction System
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Enclosed parking garages are required to have continuously running ventilation systems unless provided with approved sensor control system. Refer to the applicable mechanical code for automatic control requirements as the UMC and IMC automatic system control requirements are different.

children.body: All motor-vehicle-related occupancies shall comply with Section 406.2. Private garages and carports shall also comply with Section 406.3. Open public parking garages shall also comply with Sections 406.4 and 406.5. Enclosed public parking garages shall also comply with Sections 406.4 and 406.6. Motor fuel-dispensing facilities shall also comply with Section 406.7. Repair garages shall also comply with Section 406.8.
Private garages and carports, open and enclosed public parking garages, motor fuel-dispensing facilities and repair garages shall comply with Sections 406.2.1 through 406.2.9.

diagrams.title: Open Parking Garage vs. Open Parking Structure requirements
diagrams.descriptionHtml: The main differences between an open parking garage and an open parking structure are that only an open parking garages have a min. clear height and are limited to construction types I, II, and IV. Both open garages and open parking structures require a lot of ventilation, in open parking structures the open wall area is based on area per linear foot while in open parking garage open wall area is based on a percent of wall area and perimeter length.

diagrams.title: Private Garage Separation from Dwelling Units (BC)
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
Because the garage is a motor vehicle related occupancy there are special requirements in the code. Section 406.3.2 specifically addresses the fire separation and protection requirements for a private garage that is constructed directly adjacent to or as part of a dwelling unit. The garage is required to be separated from the dwelling unit and its attic area by means of gypsum board, not less than 1/2 inch (12.7 mm) in thickness, applied to the garage side. If there is a habitable room located above the garage, then a 5/8-inch Type X gypsum board or equivalent and 1/2-inch gypsum board separation is required on the garage side where the condition exists. Structural elements in the garage supporting the habitable spaces will also require 1/2-inch gypsum board separation.

Example: A post or a wall in the garage that supports a habitable floor above the garage space will require 1/2-inch gypsum board separation. The code then goes on to define door opening requirements for openings between a private garage and a dwelling unit. The leaf itself shall be constructed of either solid wood doors or solid or honeycomb core steel doors not less than 1-3/8 inches in thickness, or doors in compliance with Section 716.2.2.1 with a fire protection rating of not less than 20 minutes. The door is required to be self-closing, this need is typically accomplished w/ spring loaded hinges or a door closer. The door is also required to be self-latching, and this is typically accomplished by the use of an appropriate lockset. Ducts located in the garage and ducts that penetrate walls or ceilings that separate the dwelling unit including the attic spaces from the garage are required to be constructed of sheet steel of not less than 0.019 inch (0.48 mm) in thickness and shall not have openings into the garage.

children.body: Where provided, automatic garage door operators shall be listed and labeled in accordance with UL 325. Where provided, automatic vehicular gates shall comply with Section 3110.
children.displayTitle: 406.2.1 Automatic Garage Door Operators and Vehicular Gates
children.titleText: Automatic Garage Door Operators and Vehicular Gates

children.body:
The clear height of each floor level in vehicle and pedestrian traffic areas shall be not less than 7 feet (2134 mm). Canopies under which fuels are dispensed shall have a clear height in accordance with Section 406.7.2.
Exception: A lower clear height is permitted for a parking tier in mechanical-access open parking garages where approved by the building official.

diagrams.title: Min. Means of Egress Ceiling Heights
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Provisions for minimum ceiling heights include the minimum allowed heights to ceilings, protrusions, headers and other structural elements and mechanical or plumbing systems including fire sprinklers. The provisions provide allowances in dwelling units for the provision of space for ventilation in corridors (by use of a reduced ceiling height) or the condition where a room walls include the sloping roof, which reduces the ceiling height in a portion of the room. There are exceptions in the existing building code where pre-existing non-conforming ceiling heights may be allowed to remain.

children.body: Where parking is provided, accessible parking spaces, access aisles and vehicular routes serving accessible parking shall be provided in accordance with Section 1106.

diagrams.title: Vertical Clearances for Accessible Van Spaces
diagrams.descriptionHtml: ADA Advisory 502.5 Vertical Clearance. Signs provided at entrances to parking facilities informing drivers of clearances and the location of van accessible parking spaces can provide useful customer assistance.

diagrams.title: Multiple Parking Lots on a Site
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
Accessible parking spaces are required for each parking facility on a site, such as lots and garages. Requirements apply equally to public and employee or restricted parking. On sites with multiple parking facilities, the minimum number of accessible spaces must be calculated separately for each parking facility instead of on the combined total of parking spaces provided on the site.

Advisory 208.3.1 General Exception 2. Factors that could affect "user convenience" include, but are not limited to, protection from the weather, security, lighting, and comparative maintenance of the alternative parking site.

diagrams.title: Example: Accessible parking in multiple lots
diagrams.descriptionHtml: The number of required accessible parking spaces is determined individually for each parking facility, example a parking lot or a parking garage. Where there are multiple parking facilities located on the same lot, the required accessible parking spaces required in each facility is calculated separately.

diagrams.title: Parking Garages: Accessible Parking
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Accessible spaces, including van spaces, must be located so that they provide the same level of protection and security as other spaces in the garage. Locating accessible spaces required for a garage on the exterior is not usually acceptable.

children.body:
Floor surfaces shall be of concrete or similar approved noncombustible and nonabsorbent materials. The area of floor used for the parking of automobiles or other vehicles shall be sloped to facilitate the movement of liquids to a drain or toward the main vehicle entry doorway. The surface of vehicle fueling pads in motor fuel-dispensing facilities shall be in accordance with Section 406.7.1.
Exceptions:
  1. Asphalt parking surfaces shall be permitted at ground level for public parking garages and private carports.
  2. Slip-resistant, nonabsorbent, interior floor finishes having a critical radiant flux not more than 0.45 W/cm2, as determined by ASTM E648 or NFPA 253, shall be permitted in repair garages.
Openings between a motor vehicle-related occupancy and a room used for sleeping purposes shall not be permitted.
The dispensing of fuel shall only be permitted in motor fuel-dispensing facilities in accordance with Section 406.7.

Where provided, electric vehicle charging systems shall be installed in accordance with NFPA 70. Electric vehicle charging system equipment shall be listed and labeled in accordance with UL 2202. Electric vehicle supply equipment shall be listed and labeled in accordance with UL 2594. Accessibility to electric vehicle charging stations shall be provided in accordance with Section 1107.

diagrams.title: EV Charging Station Location within a Site
diagrams.descriptionHtml: According to Building Code section 1107.2.1, Not less than 5% of vehicle spaces on the site served by Electrical Vehicle charging systems, but not fewer than 1 of each type, shall be accessible. Therefore, an EV charging station must connect to an accessible route that leads to an accessible entrance of the building or facilities on the same site.

diagrams.title: EV Charging Station Clearances
diagrams.descriptionHtml: At least one of each type of Electric Vehicle charger, except those in specified Group R occupancies, are required to be accessible. The accessible EV charger shall provide a clear floor or ground space complying with section 305 and be located on an accessible route. Additional space may be required where the clear floor or ground space is confined on three sides and obstructed for more than half the depth (e.g., bollards, curbs, etc.).

diagrams.title: EV Accessible Charging Stations
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
The ADA Standards do not include specific provisions for electric vehicle (EV) charging stations. However, state and local regulations may have specific requirements.

The Access Board advises that if provided, accessible spaces at EV charging stations cannot count toward the minimum number of accessible car and van parking spaces required in a parking facility.

children.displayTitle: 406.2.7 Electric Vehicle Charging Stations and Systems
children.titleText: Electric Vehicle Charging Stations and Systems

children.body: Mixed uses shall be allowed in the same building as public parking garages and repair garages in accordance with Section 508.1. Mixed uses in the same building as an open parking garage are subject to Sections 402.4.2.3, 406.5.11, 508.1, 510.3, 510.4 and 510.7.

diagrams.title: Open Parking Garage Beneath Groups A, I, B, M and R
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Where a group A, I, B, M or R building is above an Open Parking Garage the allowable height and area for the building above and the garage are determined by different sections of the code. The height and area of the garage is dictated by section 406.5. The height and area of the building above is determined by section 503, includes the height and stories of the garage and is measured from grade plane. The two buildings need to be separated by fire barriers or horizontal assemblies with fire resistance ratings per Table 508.4 for the two uses. 2 hour fire-resistance rated fire barriers or horizontal assemblies are required to separate the means of egress for the upper building from the garage.

children.body: Equipment and appliances shall be installed in accordance with Sections 406.2.9.1 through 406.2.9.3 and the state mechanical code, rule 661—301.9(103A) and NFPA 70.

diagrams.title: Appliance Locations: Public and Private Garages

children.body:
Equipment and appliances having an ignition source and located in hazardous locations and public garages, private garages, repair garages, automotive motor fuel-dispensing facilities and parking garages shall be elevated such that the source of ignition is not less than 18 inches (457 mm) above the floor surface on which the equipment or appliance rests. For the purpose of this section, rooms or spaces that are not part of the living space of a dwelling unit and that communicate directly with a private garage through openings shall be considered to be part of the private garage.
Exception: Elevation of the ignition source is not required for appliances that are listed as flammable vapor ignition resistant.

diagrams.title: Vehicular Barriers for Equipment: Examples
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Mechanical and gas fired appliances require protection from vehicular impact. These are some examples of options as illustrated in the Oregon Mechanical Code. For vehicular protection of devices regulated by the Fire Code, also see Guard Posts as described in Fire Code Section 312.2 or verify what approved means of protection is allowed by the fire code authority in your jurisdiction.

diagrams.title: Water Heater: Garages
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Water heaters placed in residential garages have specific requirements for protection from damage. Water heaters in commercial settings have additional requirements, including compliance with other codes.

diagrams.title: Elevation of Ignition Sources
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Any equipment or appliance having a flame, spark, or hot surface as an ignition source is required to be a minimum of 18" above the finished floor in hazardous occupancies, garages, and fuel facilities.These types of equipment and appliances are not permitted to be installed withing Group H occupancies where handling, use, or dispensing of combustible, flammable, or explosive products is conducted.

children.body:
Connection of a parking garage with any room in which there is a fuel-fired appliance shall be by means of a vestibule providing a two-doorway separation, except that a single door is permitted where the sources of ignition in the appliance are elevated in accordance with Section 406.2.9.
Exception: This section shall not apply to appliance installations complying with Section 406.2.9.2 or 406.2.9.3.

diagrams.title: Fuel-Fired Appliances at Parking Garages
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Any room containing a fuel-fired appliance is required to be separated from a private garage by a 2 doorways and a vestibule. Where the ignition source of the appliance is elevated 18" from the garage floor in accordance with section 304.3 a single door is permitted. For public garage see section 304.6.

children.body:
Appliances located in public garages, motor fuel-dispensing facilities, repair garages or other areas frequented by motor vehicles shall be installed not less than 8 feet (2438 mm) above the floor. Where motor vehicles are capable of passing under an appliance, the appliance shall be installed at the clearances required by the appliance manufacturer and not less than 1 foot (305 mm) higher than the tallest vehicle garage door opening.
Exception: The requirements of this section shall not apply where the appliances are protected from motor vehicle impact and installed in accordance with Section 406.2.9.1 and NFPA 30A.

diagrams.title: Appliance Locations: Public and Private Garages

children.body:
Appliances located in private garages and carports shall be installed with a minimum clearance of 6 feet (1829 mm) above the floor.
Exception: The requirements of this section shall not apply where the appliances are protected from motor vehicle impact and are installed in accordance with Section 406.2.9.1.

diagrams.title: Vehicular Barriers for Equipment: Examples
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Mechanical and gas fired appliances require protection from vehicular impact. These are some examples of options as illustrated in the Oregon Mechanical Code. For vehicular protection of devices regulated by the Fire Code, also see Guard Posts as described in Fire Code Section 312.2 or verify what approved means of protection is allowed by the fire code authority in your jurisdiction.

diagrams.title: Appliance Locations: Public and Private Garages

children.body: Private garages and carports shall comply with Sections 406.2 and 406.3, or they shall comply with Sections 406.2 and 406.4.

diagrams.title: Private Garage Separation from Dwelling Units (BC)
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
Because the garage is a motor vehicle related occupancy there are special requirements in the code. Section 406.3.2 specifically addresses the fire separation and protection requirements for a private garage that is constructed directly adjacent to or as part of a dwelling unit. The garage is required to be separated from the dwelling unit and its attic area by means of gypsum board, not less than 1/2 inch (12.7 mm) in thickness, applied to the garage side. If there is a habitable room located above the garage, then a 5/8-inch Type X gypsum board or equivalent and 1/2-inch gypsum board separation is required on the garage side where the condition exists. Structural elements in the garage supporting the habitable spaces will also require 1/2-inch gypsum board separation.

Example: A post or a wall in the garage that supports a habitable floor above the garage space will require 1/2-inch gypsum board separation. The code then goes on to define door opening requirements for openings between a private garage and a dwelling unit. The leaf itself shall be constructed of either solid wood doors or solid or honeycomb core steel doors not less than 1-3/8 inches in thickness, or doors in compliance with Section 716.2.2.1 with a fire protection rating of not less than 20 minutes. The door is required to be self-closing, this need is typically accomplished w/ spring loaded hinges or a door closer. The door is also required to be self-latching, and this is typically accomplished by the use of an appropriate lockset. Ducts located in the garage and ducts that penetrate walls or ceilings that separate the dwelling unit including the attic spaces from the garage are required to be constructed of sheet steel of not less than 0.019 inch (0.48 mm) in thickness and shall not have openings into the garage.

children.body: Private garages and carports shall be classified as Group U occupancies. Each private garage shall be not greater than 1,000 square feet (93 m2) in area. Multiple private garages are permitted in a building where each private garage is separated from the other private garages by 1-hour fire barriers in accordance with Section 707, or 1-hour horizontal assemblies in accordance with Section 711, or both.

For other than private garages adjacent to dwelling units, the separation of private garages from other occupancies shall comply with Section 508. Separation of private garages from dwelling units shall comply with Sections 406.3.2.1 and 406.3.2.2.

diagrams.title: Private Garage Separation from Dwelling Units (BC)
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
Because the garage is a motor vehicle related occupancy there are special requirements in the code. Section 406.3.2 specifically addresses the fire separation and protection requirements for a private garage that is constructed directly adjacent to or as part of a dwelling unit. The garage is required to be separated from the dwelling unit and its attic area by means of gypsum board, not less than 1/2 inch (12.7 mm) in thickness, applied to the garage side. If there is a habitable room located above the garage, then a 5/8-inch Type X gypsum board or equivalent and 1/2-inch gypsum board separation is required on the garage side where the condition exists. Structural elements in the garage supporting the habitable spaces will also require 1/2-inch gypsum board separation.

Example: A post or a wall in the garage that supports a habitable floor above the garage space will require 1/2-inch gypsum board separation. The code then goes on to define door opening requirements for openings between a private garage and a dwelling unit. The leaf itself shall be constructed of either solid wood doors or solid or honeycomb core steel doors not less than 1-3/8 inches in thickness, or doors in compliance with Section 716.2.2.1 with a fire protection rating of not less than 20 minutes. The door is required to be self-closing, this need is typically accomplished w/ spring loaded hinges or a door closer. The door is also required to be self-latching, and this is typically accomplished by the use of an appropriate lockset. Ducts located in the garage and ducts that penetrate walls or ceilings that separate the dwelling unit including the attic spaces from the garage are required to be constructed of sheet steel of not less than 0.019 inch (0.48 mm) in thickness and shall not have openings into the garage.

children.body: The private garage shall be separated from the dwelling unit and its attic area by means of gypsum board, not less than 1/2 inch (12.7 mm) in thickness, applied to the garage side. Garages beneath habitable rooms shall be separated from all habitable rooms above by not less than a 5/8-inch (15.9 mm) Type X gypsum board or equivalent and 1/2-inch (12.7 mm) gypsum board applied to structures supporting the separation from habitable rooms above the garage. Door openings between a private garage and the dwelling unit shall be equipped with either solid wood doors or solid or honeycomb core steel doors not less than 13/8 inches (34.9 mm) in thickness, or doors in compliance with Section 716.2.2.1 with a fire protection rating of not less than 20 minutes. Doors shall be self-closing and self-latching.

Ducts in a private garage and ducts penetrating the walls or ceilings separating the dwelling unit from the garage, including its attic area, shall be constructed of sheet steel of not less than 0.019 inch (0.48 mm) in thickness and shall not have openings into the garage.

diagrams.title: Mechanical Protection - Ducts
diagrams.descriptionHtml: The mechanical code requires protection of ductwork installed in location that may be subject to vehicle or other impact by an approved barrier.

children.body: Carports shall be open on not fewer than two sides. Carports open on fewer than two sides shall be considered to be a garage and shall comply with the requirements for private garages.
A separation is not required between a Group R-3 and U carport, provided that the carport is entirely open on two or more sides and there are not enclosed areas above.

Parking garages, other than private garages, shall be classified as public parking garages and shall comply with the provisions of Sections 406.2 and 406.4 and shall be classified as either an open parking garage or an enclosed parking garage. Open parking garages shall also comply with Section 406.5. Enclosed parking garages shall also comply with Section 406.6. See Section 510 for special provisions for parking garages.

diagrams.title: Open Parking Garage vs. Open Parking Structure requirements
diagrams.descriptionHtml: The main differences between an open parking garage and an open parking structure are that only an open parking garages have a min. clear height and are limited to construction types I, II, and IV. Both open garages and open parking structures require a lot of ventilation, in open parking structures the open wall area is based on area per linear foot while in open parking garage open wall area is based on a percent of wall area and perimeter length.

diagrams.title: Mechanical Protection - Ducts
diagrams.descriptionHtml: The mechanical code requires protection of ductwork installed in location that may be subject to vehicle or other impact by an approved barrier.

children.body: Guards shall be provided in accordance with Section 1015. Guards serving as vehicle barriers shall comply with Sections 406.4.2 and 1015.

Vehicle barriers not less than 2 feet 9 inches (835 mm) in height shall be placed where the vertical distance from the floor of a drive lane or parking space to the ground or surface directly below is greater than 1 foot (305 mm). Vehicle barriers shall comply with the loading requirements of Section 1607.11.
Exception: Vehicle barriers are not required in vehicle storage compartments in a mechanical access parking garage.

Vehicle ramps shall not be considered as required exits unless pedestrian facilities are provided. Vehicle ramps that are utilized for vertical circulation as well as for parking shall not exceed a slope of 1 unit vertical in 15 units horizontal (6.67-percent slope).

diagrams.title: Parking Garage Exiting: Vehicular Ramps
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Vehicle access ramps may not generally be used as a means of egress from a parking garage. Vehicles entering or exiting the garage pose a hazard to pedestrians.

children.body: Open parking garages shall comply with Sections 406.2, 406.4 and 406.5.

diagrams.title: Open Parking Garage vs. Open Parking Structure requirements
diagrams.descriptionHtml: The main differences between an open parking garage and an open parking structure are that only an open parking garages have a min. clear height and are limited to construction types I, II, and IV. Both open garages and open parking structures require a lot of ventilation, in open parking structures the open wall area is based on area per linear foot while in open parking garage open wall area is based on a percent of wall area and perimeter length.

diagrams.title: Open Parking Garage
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Open Parking Garage: a structure or portion of a structure with openings on two or more exterior walls that is used for the parking or storage of private motor vehicles.

diagrams.title: Open Parking Garage Beneath Groups A, I, B, M and R
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Where a group A, I, B, M or R building is above an Open Parking Garage the allowable height and area for the building above and the garage are determined by different sections of the code. The height and area of the garage is dictated by section 406.5. The height and area of the building above is determined by section 503, includes the height and stories of the garage and is measured from grade plane. The two buildings need to be separated by fire barriers or horizontal assemblies with fire resistance ratings per Table 508.4 for the two uses. 2 hour fire-resistance rated fire barriers or horizontal assemblies are required to separate the means of egress for the upper building from the garage.

diagrams.title: Sprinklers: Bldgs > 55 ft. (Ex. 1)
diagrams.descriptionHtml: If a building has an occupant load of 30 or more people on any story that is 55 feet or higher, above the lowest level of fire department access - as measured from finished floor to finished floor, then an automatic fire sprinkler system is required. This requirement does not apply to open parking garages or F-2 occupancies, low hazard factory industrial uses.

diagrams.title: Mechanical Protection - Ducts
diagrams.descriptionHtml: The mechanical code requires protection of ductwork installed in location that may be subject to vehicle or other impact by an approved barrier.

diagrams.title: Group B or M Buildings With Group S-2 Open Parking Garage Above
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
The code provides a special provision to allow for vehicle parking to be placed above a place of business or retail. For the purpose of determining the type of construction, an S-2 open parking structure may be considered separately from a group B or M occupancy building below when all of the following conditions are met:
  1. A horizontal assembly of not less than 2 hours fire-resistance separates the two buildings
  2. The occupancy of the building below is limited to group B and M
  3. The occupancy of the building above is limited to a Group S-2 open parking garage
  4. The building below the horizontal assembly is of type IA construction. Exception: Where the building below is limited to 1 story in height the construction type for the lower building may be type IB or II but not less than the construction type required by the S-2 open parking garage above.
  5. The lower building complies with the height and area limits set forth in Section 503 (table 504).
  6. The upper building complies with the height and area limits set forth in Section 406.5. The height, in both feet and stories, shall be measured from grade plane and include the building below.
  7. Exits serving the garage discharge at grade with direct access to a street or public way and are separated from the building below by 2-hour fire barriers, 2-hour horizontal assemblies or both.

children.body: Open parking garages shall be of Type I, II or IV construction. Open parking garages shall meet the design requirements of Chapter 16. For vehicle barriers, see Section 406.4.2.

For natural ventilation purposes, the exterior side of the structure shall have uniformly distributed openings on two or more sides. The area of such openings in exterior walls on a tier shall be not less than 20 percent of the total perimeter wall area of each tier. The aggregate length of the openings considered to be providing natural ventilation shall be not less than 40 percent of the perimeter of the tier. Interior walls shall be not less than 20 percent open with uniformly distributed openings.
Exception: Openings are not required to be distributed over 40 percent of the building perimeter where the required openings are uniformly distributed over two opposing sides of the building.

diagrams.title: Open Parking Garage
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Open Parking Garage: a structure or portion of a structure with openings on two or more exterior walls that is used for the parking or storage of private motor vehicles.

children.body: Where openings below grade provide required natural ventilation, the outside horizontal clear space shall be one and one-half times the depth of the opening. The width of the horizontal clear space shall be maintained from grade down to the bottom of the lowest required opening.

diagrams.title: Natural Ventilation Openings Below Grade (IMC)
diagrams.descriptionHtml: In the Mechanical Code, natural ventilation for areas below grade does not have the advantage of breezes or the direct natural flow of air at the ground level. Therefore, a larger opening of the window well is required to provide the air needed. Where below grade windows are also used as emergency escape openings, window wells shall comply with the more restrictive of natural ventilation or minimum window well sizes for emergency escape windows.

children.body: Mixed uses shall be allowed in the same building as an open parking garage subject to the provisions of Sections 402.4.2.3, 406.5.11, 508.1, 510.3, 510.4 and 510.7.

diagrams.title: Podiums: Parking Beneath Group R
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
Section 510.4 allows for the increase of one story above a Type I closed/open garage or Type IV open garage with a horizontal assembly with a fire resistive rating equal to that of 508.4 or the required type of construction, whichever is greater. Section 406.5.3 allows open parking garages complying with 510.4 to be mixed use occupancies. Depending on the other occupancy groups below the R occupancy it is possible areas could require a greater fire-resistance rating than is required for the type of construction.

Some literature suggests that a lesser rating can be applied to the floor of type IV construction. However, the wording of the code section does not seem to provide that option. Heavy timber construction for floors is based on a prescriptive size of wood members. Mass timber construction requires a minimum floor rating of 2 hours, and only footnote a of Table 601 allows for reduction of ratings of a floor rating. It does not appear the code allows for reduction of the floor rating to 1 hour, as some suggest.

The user should also be aware that starting with the 2021 year edition, sections of 903.3.1.2 more severely restricts the use of NFPA 13R systems for this condition to the grade plane, instead of the horizontal assembly above the garage.

diagrams.title: Open Parking Garage Beneath Groups A, I, B, M and R
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Where a group A, I, B, M or R building is above an Open Parking Garage the allowable height and area for the building above and the garage are determined by different sections of the code. The height and area of the garage is dictated by section 406.5. The height and area of the building above is determined by section 503, includes the height and stories of the garage and is measured from grade plane. The two buildings need to be separated by fire barriers or horizontal assemblies with fire resistance ratings per Table 508.4 for the two uses. 2 hour fire-resistance rated fire barriers or horizontal assemblies are required to separate the means of egress for the upper building from the garage.

diagrams.title: Group S-2 Enclosed Parking Garage With Group S-2 Open Parking Garage Above
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
A Group S-2 enclosed parking garage with no more than one story above grade plane, located beneath a Group S-2 open parking garage, is considered a separate building for construction type purposes if the following conditions are met:
  • The sum of area actual area to allowable area ratios of both occupancies must not exceed 1;
  • The enclosed garage is of type I or II construction and has equal or greater fire resistance than required for the open parking garage;
  • The open garage complies with height and tier limits in Table 406.5.4;
  • The floor assembly separating the two types of garages must meet the enclosed garage's fire protection requirements;
  • Openings other than exit openings between the two garage types are not required to be protected;
  • And the enclosed garage must be used solely for private vehicle parking or storage.
An accessory use area up to 1000 sf that may contain an office, waiting room, and toilet room is allowed in the enclosed garage. The enclosed garage may also contain a mechanical room that serves the building.

children.body: Area and height of open parking garages shall be limited as set forth in Chapter 5 for Group S-2 occupancies and as further provided for in Section 508.1.

Where the open parking garage is used exclusively for the parking or storage of private motor vehicles, and the building is without other uses, the area and height shall be permitted to comply with Table 406.5.4, along with increases allowed by Section 406.5.5.
Exception: The grade-level tier is permitted to contain an office, waiting and toilet rooms having a total combined area of not more than 1,000 square feet (93 m2). Such area need not be separated from the open parking garage.
In open parking garages having a spiral or sloping floor, the horizontal projection of the structure at any cross section shall not exceed the allowable area per parking tier. In the case of an open parking garage having a continuous spiral floor, each 9 feet 6 inches (2896 mm) of height, or portion thereof, shall be considered under these provisions to be a tier.

The allowable area and height of open parking garages shall be increased in accordance with the provisions of this section. Garages with sides open on three-fourths of the building's perimeter are permitted to be increased by 25 percent in area and one tier in height. Garages with sides open around the entire building's perimeter are permitted to be increased by 50 percent in area and one tier in height. For a side to be considered open under these provisions, the total area of openings along the side shall be not less than 50 percent of the interior area of the side at each tier and such openings shall be equally distributed along the length of the tier. For purposes of calculating the interior area of the side, the height shall not exceed 7 feet (2134 mm).
Allowable tier areas in Table 406.5.4 shall be increased for open parking garages constructed to heights less than the table maximum. The gross tier area of the garage shall not exceed that permitted for the higher structure. Not fewer than three sides of each such larger tier shall have continuous horizontal openings not less than 30 inches (762 mm) in clear height extending for not less than 80 percent of the length of the sides. All parts of such larger tier shall be not more than 200 feet (60 960 mm) horizontally from such an opening. In addition, each such opening shall face a street or yard with access to a street with a width of not less than 30 feet (9144 mm) for the full length of the opening, and standpipes shall be provided in each such tier.
Open parking garages of Type II construction, with all sides open, shall be unlimited in allowable area where the building height does not exceed 75 feet (22 860 mm). For a side to be considered open, the total area of openings along the side shall be not less than 50 percent of the interior area of the side at each tier and such openings shall be equally distributed along the length of the tier. For purposes of calculating the interior area of the side, the height shall not exceed 7 feet (2134 mm). All portions of tiers shall be within 200 feet (60 960 mm) horizontally from such openings or other natural ventilation openings as defined in Section 406.5.2. These openings shall be permitted to be provided in courts with a minimum dimension of 20 feet (6096 mm) for the full width of the openings.
Exterior walls and openings in exterior walls shall comply with Table 601 and Table 705.5. The distance to an adjacent lot line shall be determined in accordance with Section 705 and Table 705.5.

Where persons other than parking attendants are permitted, open parking garages shall meet the means of egress requirements of Chapter 10. Where persons other than parking attendants are not permitted, there shall be not fewer than two exit stairways. Each exit stairway shall be not less than 36 inches (914 mm) in width. Lifts shall be permitted to be installed for use of employees only, provided that they are completely enclosed by noncombustible materials.
An open parking garage shall be equipped with a standpipe system as required by Section 905.3.

diagrams.title: Standpipe Types
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Standpipes, Types: - There are five types of standpipes - automatic dry, automatic wet, manual dry, manual wet, and semiautomatic dry. Automatic dry systems are pressurized with air, when a hose valve is opened, the air is released and the system fills with water. Automatic wet systems are filled with water at all times. Manual dry systems are not connected to a water supply, and must be supplied with water from the fire department. This is done via a fire department connection (FDC). Manual wet systems are filled with water, but require a supplemental fire department connection to meet required demand. Semiautomatic dry systems do not have water in them, but when a hose valve is opened, a remote switch opens the valve and allows water to fill the system.

diagrams.title: Standpipe System Classes
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
Standpipe Systems - There are three classification of standpipes:
  • Class I standpipes are equipped with a 2-1/2" hose connection and are intended for fire department use only.
  • Class II standpipes are equipped with a 1-1/2" hose and connection, and are intended primarily for building occupant use.
  • Class III standpipes are equipped with a 2-1/2" hose connection, reduced down to a 1-1/2" connected hose. These are intended for use by building occupants and fire department personnel.

children.body: Enclosure shall not be required for vertical openings except as specified in Section 406.5.7.
Ventilation, other than the percentage of openings specified in Section 406.5.2, shall not be required.

The following uses and alterations are not permitted:
  1. Vehicle repair work.
  2. Parking of buses, trucks and similar vehicles.
  3. Partial or complete closing of required openings in exterior walls by tarpaulins or any other means.
  4. Dispensing of fuel.
Enclosed parking garages shall comply with Sections 406.2, 406.4 and 406.6.

diagrams.title: Mechanical Protection - Ducts
diagrams.descriptionHtml: The mechanical code requires protection of ductwork installed in location that may be subject to vehicle or other impact by an approved barrier.

diagrams.title: Enclosed Parking Garage Ventilation - Ducted System
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Enclosed parking garages are required to have continuously running ventilation systems unless provided with approved sensor control system. Refer to the applicable mechanical code for automatic control requirements as the UMC and IMC automatic system control requirements are different.

diagrams.title: Enclosed Parking Garage Ventilation - Ductless Jet-Induction System
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Enclosed parking garages are required to have continuously running ventilation systems unless provided with approved sensor control system. Refer to the applicable mechanical code for automatic control requirements as the UMC and IMC automatic system control requirements are different.

children.body: Enclosed vehicle parking garages and portions thereof that do not meet the definition of open parking garages shall be limited to the allowable heights and areas specified in Sections 504 and 506 as modified by Section 507. Roof parking is permitted.

diagrams.title: Open Spaces for Unlimited Area Bldgs.
diagrams.descriptionHtml: The proper way to measure required yard space is from the perimeter of the building to the lot line, or face of another building on the same lot. A public way is measured for the entire width of the public way, not just for the portion of the building that fronts the public way.

children.body:
A mechanical ventilation system and exhaust system shall be provided in accordance with Chapters 4 and 5 of the state mechanical code.
Exception: Mechanical ventilation shall not be required for enclosed parking garages that are accessory to one- and two-family dwellings.
An enclosed parking garage shall be equipped with an automatic sprinkler system in accordance with Section 903.2.10.
Mechanical-access enclosed parking garages shall be in accordance with Sections 406.6.4.1 through 406.6.4.4.

diagrams.title: Stories with Single Exits - Condition 3
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
Where any one of the following conditions is met any story or occupied roof space may have single exit:
Condition 1: The Exit access travel distance, occupant load and number of dwelling units do not exceed the values in Table 1006.3.4(1) or Table 1006.3.4(2)
Condition 2: Rooms, areas and spaces that comply with Section 1006.2.1 and have exits that discharge directly to the exterior at the level of exit discharge
Condition 3: Parking garage where vehicles are mechanically parked
Condition 4: Group R-3 and R-4 occupancies
Condition 5: Individual Dwelling Units that comply with section 1006.2.1 that exit directly to the exterior or exit to exit access that provides access to two approved independent exits.

children.body: Mechanical-access enclosed parking garages shall be separated from other occupancies and accessory uses by not less than 2-hour fire barriers constructed in accordance with Section 707 or by not less than 2-hour horizontal assemblies constructed in accordance with Section 711, or both.
A mechanical smoke removal system, installed in accordance with Section 910.4, shall be provided for all areas containing a mechanical-access enclosed parking garage.

Fire control equipment, consisting of the fire alarm control unit, mechanical ventilation controls and an emergency shutdown switch, shall be provided in a room located where the equipment is able to be accessed by the fire service from a secured exterior door of the building. The room shall be not less than 50 square feet (4.65 m2) in area and shall be in a location that is approved by the fire code official.

The mechanical parking system shall be provided with a manually activated emergency shutdown switch for use by emergency personnel. The switch shall be clearly identified and shall be in a location approved by the fire code official.
Access doors shall be provided in accordance with Section 3206.7 of the International Fire Code.
Motor fuel-dispensing facilities shall comply with the International Fire Code and Sections 406.2 and 406.7.
The vehicle shall be fueled on noncoated concrete or other approved paving material having a resistance not exceeding 1 megohm as determined by the methodology in CEN EN 1081.

Canopies under which fuels are dispensed shall have a clear, unobstructed height of not less than 13 feet 6 inches (4115 mm) to the lowest projecting element in the vehicle drive-through area. Canopies and their supports over pumps shall be of noncombustible materials, fire-retardant-treated wood complying with Chapter 23, heavy timber complying with Section 2304.11 or construction providing 1-hour fire resistance. Combustible materials used in or on a canopy shall comply with one of the following:
  1. Shielded from the pumps by a noncombustible element of the canopy, or heavy timber complying with Section 2304.11.
  2. Plastics covered by aluminum facing having a thickness of not less than 0.010 inch (0.30 mm) or corrosion-resistant steel having a base metal thickness of not less than 0.016 inch (0.41 mm). The plastic shall have a flame spread index of 25 or less and a smoke-developed index of 450 or less when tested in the form intended for use in accordance with ASTM E84 or UL 723 and a self-ignition temperature of 650°F (343°C) or greater when tested in accordance with ASTM D1929.
  3. Panels constructed of light-transmitting plastic materials shall be permitted to be installed in canopies erected over motor vehicle fuel-dispensing station fuel dispensers, provided that the panels are located not less than 10 feet (3048 mm) from any building on the same lot and face yards or streets not less than 40 feet (12 192 mm) in width on the other sides. The aggregate areas of plastics shall be not greater than 1,000 square feet (93 m2). The maximum area of any individual panel shall be not greater than 100 square feet (9.3 m2).

Canopies that are used to shelter dispensing operations where flammable compressed gases are located on the roof of the canopy shall be in accordance with the following:
  1. The canopy shall meet or exceed Type I construction requirements.
  2. Operations located under canopies shall be limited to refueling only.
  3. The canopy shall be constructed in a manner that prevents the accumulation of hydrogen gas.
children.displayTitle: 406.7.2.1 Canopies Used to Support Gaseous Hydrogen Systems
children.titleText: Canopies Used to Support Gaseous Hydrogen Systems

children.body: Repair garages shall be constructed in accordance with the International Fire Code and Sections 406.2 and 406.8. This occupancy shall not include motor fuel-dispensing facilities, as regulated in Section 406.7.
Repair garages shall be mechanically ventilated in accordance with the state mechanical code. The ventilation system shall be controlled at the entrance to the garage.

Repair garages used for repair of vehicles fueled by nonodorized gases including but not limited to hydrogen and nonodorized LNG, shall be provided with a gas detection system that complies with Section 916. The gas detection system shall be designed to detect leakage of nonodorized gaseous fuel. Where lubrication or chassis service pits are provided in garages used for repairing nonodorized LNG-fueled vehicles, gas sensors shall be provided in such pits.

Activation of a gas detection alarm shall result in all of the following:
  1. Initiation of distinct audible and visual alarm signals in the repair garage, where the ventilation system is interlocked with gas detection.
  2. Deactivation of all heating systems located in the repair garage.
  3. Activation of the mechanical ventilation system, where the system is interlocked with gas detection.

Failure of the gas detection system shall automatically deactivate the heating system, activate the mechanical ventilation system where the system is interlocked with the gas detection system, and cause a trouble signal to sound at an approved location.
children.displayTitle: [F]  406.8.2.2 Failure of the Gas Detection System
children.titleText: Failure of the Gas Detection System

children.body: A repair garage shall be equipped with an automatic sprinkler system in accordance with Section 903.2.9.1.

diagrams.title: Admissions Area Requirements
diagrams.descriptionHtml: The hospital guidelines call out the minimum programmatic requirements for the Admissions Area. An admissions area is required to contain a waiting area for both patients and persons accompanying the patient. A work counter is required for the admissions staff. Space for wheelchair storage that is not within the required path of egress travel is also required.

diagrams.title: Wheelchair Storage and Parking (Hospital)
diagrams.descriptionHtml: The code ensures that the disabled have reasonable access to and places to store wheelchairs that do not hinder egress. Wheelchair storage in facilities that provide wheelchairs is required to be out of the required means of egress and directly accessible to the entrance for at least one wheelchair. Where patients will be required to transfer from a wheelchair a parking area for at least one wheelchair must be provided that is both in a non-public area and out of any required egress width or required clearances.

diagrams.title: NICU Sound Ratings
diagrams.descriptionHtml: In order to ensure that neonatal intensive care unit's (NICU) environments are sufficiently quiet for the new born patients, the code calls for minimum sound transmissions coefficients (STC) for the various walls, floors and ceilings that separate NICU's from other functions within the hospital. The required STC separation rating is called out in table A2.2-a, varies from 40 to 65 and is dependent on the adjacent spaces use/function.

diagrams.title: General Rm. Type Reqs. - Operating Rm.
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
Because the security and infection control requirements for various types hospital procedure rooms varies depending on the sanitary, infection control, privacy and security needs for different types of procedures being performed Table 2.2-1 (in 2018) is provided. The table defines the specific needs of the various procedure rooms in a hospital to ensure the rooms can be adequately cleaned and provide the privacy and infection control needed for various exams, treatments, procedures and operations to take place safely.

In 2022, the imaging classification was substituted for the description of the spaces. The designer will need to know the intended program for each room to determine each imaging room's procedural classification. In the 2022 edition, this table has been removed and the requirements are spread throughout various sections for those specific spaces.

diagrams.title: Level 2 Alterations: Group I-2 Corridor Widths
General Rm. Type Reqs. - Procedure Rm.
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
Because the security and infection control requirements for various types hospital procedure rooms varies depending on the sanitary, infection control, privacy and security needs for different types of procedures being performed Table 2.2-1 (in 2018) is provided. The table defines the specific needs of the various procedure rooms in a hospital to ensure the rooms can be adequately cleaned and provide the privacy and infection control needed for various exams, treatments, procedures and operations to take place safely.

In 2022, the imaging classification was substituted for the description of the spaces. The designer will need to know the intended program for each room to determine each imaging room's procedural classification. In the 2022 edition, this table has been removed and the requirements are spread throughout various sections for those specific spaces.

diagrams.title: General Rm. Type Reqs. - Exam / Treatment Rm.
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
Because the security and infection control requirements for various types hospital procedure rooms varies depending on the sanitary, infection control, privacy and security needs for different types of procedures being performed Table 2.2-1 (in 2018) is provided. The table defines the specific needs of the various procedure rooms in a hospital to ensure the rooms can be adequately cleaned and provide the privacy and infection control needed for various exams, treatments, procedures and operations to take place safely.

In 2022, the imaging classification was substituted for the description of the spaces. The designer will need to know the intended program for each room to determine each imaging room's procedural classification. In the 2022 edition, this table has been removed and the requirements are spread throughout various sections for those specific spaces.

diagrams.title: Patient Care Unit Room Type Reqs. - Class 3 Imaging
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Because the security and infection control requirements for various types of patient Imaging service rooms varies depending on the sanitary, infection control, privacy and security needs for different types of imaging services table 2.2-2 is provided. The table defines the specific needs of the various imaging service rooms to ensure the rooms can be adequately cleaned and provide the privacy and infection control needed for different imaging services. The designer will need to know the intended program for each imaging room to determine each imaging room's classification.

diagrams.title: Patient Care Unit Room Type Reqs. - Class 2 Imaging
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Because the security and infection control requirements for various types of patient Imaging service rooms varies depending on the sanitary, infection control, privacy and security needs for different types of imaging services table 2.2-2 is provided. The table defines the specific needs of the various imaging service rooms to ensure the rooms can be adequately cleaned and provide the privacy and infection control needed for different imaging services. The designer will need to know the intended program for each imaging room to determine each imaging room's classification.

diagrams.title: Patient Care Unit Room Type Reqs. - Class 1 Imaging
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Because the security and infection control requirements for various types of patient Imaging service rooms varies depending on the sanitary, infection control, privacy and security needs for different types of imaging services table 2.2-2 is provided. The table defines the specific needs of the various imaging service rooms to ensure the rooms can be adequately cleaned and provide the privacy and infection control needed for different imaging services. The designer will need to know the intended program for each imaging room to determine each imaging room's classification.

diagrams.title: Grab Bars (Hospital)
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Because patients will be counting on grab bars being able to support them, the code defines the minimum loading that a grab bar must be able to resist as a concentrated load of 250 pounds. The load may be applied at any point and in any direction along the grab bar. Because some patients are individuals of size the code calls for grab bars serving them to be able to resist a concentrated load of 800 pounds applied at any point and in any direction along the length of the grab bar. To ensure maximum safety the ends of grab bars need to be designed to prevent the snagging of clothing, typically achieved by returning the grab bar end to a wall or floor. The hospital guideline also advises that the finish should contrast the adjacent wall finish and that the bar should provide for a slip resistant gripping surface.

diagrams.title: Hospital Elevators: Dimension and Clearances
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Because patient occupied beds and attendants need to be transported by the elevators, hospital elevator car clear floor space and door size is defined in the code. The hospital code calls for the clear floor of the car to be 5'-8" minimum wide by 9' minimum deep. The hospital code calls for elevator car doors to have clear opening 48" minimum wide by 84" minimum tall. The car and doorway dimensions are a minimum guide, a larger clear floor space and door opening may be needed to address special facility needs, such as and ICU where multiple attendants and equipment may also need to be transported with the patient. The hospital code allows for elevators provided beyond the minimum needed for patient transport that are for visitor or material handling to be smaller.

diagrams.title: Patient Room Size and Clearances
diagrams.descriptionHtml: To ensure adequate room is provided in patient rooms the code defines a minimum clear area and minimum clearances required from the bed to a wall or fixed obstruction. For Single-patient rooms the minimum clear area is 120 sf and the minimum clearance to the side or foot of the bed to a wall or fixed obstruction is 3'. For multiple patient rooms the minimum clear area is 100 sf per bed, 3' clear to the sides of each bed and 4' clear at the foot of each bed to a wall or fixed obstruction. The additional clearance at the foot of the bed called for in multiple-patient rooms is to allow for the passage of beds and equipment. In the event clinical services are to be provided in the room, the room may be required to exceed the minimum room requirements.

diagrams.title: Corridor Widths in Hospitals
diagrams.descriptionHtml: The Life and Safety Code and the Building Code. Section 18.2.3.4 of Life and Safety Code calls for exit access corridors to have width not less than 8'. Section 1020.3 of the building code calls for the width to be the greater width as determined by occupant load per section 1005.1 or per Table 1020.2 (or Table 1020.3). This table calls for 96" minimum width for exit access corridors in areas required for bed movement and 44" minimum width in areas where bed movement is not required. The width may be reduced to 6' at fixed furniture provided the width meets the occupant load egress required per section 1005.1 of the building code. The hospital facilities guidelines code calls for corridor width to comply with two other codes.

diagrams.title: Hand Washing Stations
diagrams.descriptionHtml: In order to minimize the spread of harmful germs the code requires handwashing stations. The locations and number of required stations are defined in sections 2.1-2.2.5 and 2.1-2.8.7.3. Handwashing stations need to include a sink and faucet that complies with Section 2.1-8.4.3.2. The sink may be wall mounted or in a countertop. If in a countertop the top may be made of porcelain, stainless steel, solid-surface materials, or impervious plastic laminate assembly. If the countertop material such as plastic laminate that requires a substrate, marine-grade plywood (or an equivalent material) with an impervious seal is required. If the sink is located in a cabinet, the cabinet must not allow for storage beneath the sink. Provisions for hand drying need to be provided. Touchless enclosed towel dispensers and touch free hot-air dryers. If a towel dispenser is provided it must be within arm's reach of the sink. A liquid or foam soap dispenser is required. Mirrors over handwashing stations sinks are not allowed at stations in the following locations food preparation areas, nurseries, clean and sterile supply areas, areas where asepsis control would be lessened by hair combing or scrub stations.

diagrams.title: Hospital Reception Areas or Lobbies
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
Because there will likely be a disproportionate number of disabled people served by a hospital in comparison to other businesses, the hospital guidelines define what needs to be provided and accessed from within hospital lobbies and reception areas. Within the lobby the following need to be provided:
  • Access to information (typically a reception desk with an attendant).
  • A public waiting area.
  • Public toilet room(s).
  • Access to drinking water.
  • Access to public communications services (phone and internet where available).

diagrams.title: Hospital Elevators: Number required
diagrams.descriptionHtml: To ensure that adequate vertical transportation of patient beds is provided in hospitals the code defines the minimum number of "hospital-type" elevators that must be provided. Since the Hospital will be relying on the elevators to move patients if a hospital-type elevator is needed at least 2 will be required to ensure safe continued operation of the hospital in the event of an elevator breakdown. The number of required hospital-type elevators is based on the bed count and the beds' location relative to the main entry floor or a floor where major inpatient services are provided. When 1 to 59 beds are provided on a floor or floors other than the main entry floor 2 hospital-type elevators are required. When 60 to 200 patient beds are provided on a floor or floors other than the main entry floor or a floor where major inpatient services are provided 2 hospital-type elevators are required. When 201 to 350 patient beds are provided on a floor or floors other than the main entry floor or a floor where major inpatient services are provided 2 hospital-type elevators are required. When over 350 patient beds are provided a vertical transportation study based on the plans need to be conducted to determine the number of hospital-type elevators that are required.

diagrams.title: Noise Control (Hospitals)
diagrams.descriptionHtml: To ensure that patients' healing is not disturbed by excessive noise, the hospital guideline has noise criteria that applies to patient areas. To protect the patients from being disturbed by impact noises recreation, exercise, equipment and similar spaces that generate impact noises are not allowed to be directly over patient bed areas, deliver or operating suites unless special noise reduction provisions are provided. To ensure that patient areas are sufficiently quiet the FGI provides minimum STC (sound transmission class) criteria in table 1.2-6 for patient area ceilings, floors and walls.

diagrams.title: Handrails at Hospital Corridors
diagrams.descriptionHtml: The hospital guidelines call for handrails on both sides of corridors used by patients. Rails are require to be continuous with exceptions being made for doors, nurses stations, alcoves, fire extinguisher cabinets and where features are less than 24" apart (2022). Railing ends are required to return wall or floor. The gripping surface is required to be smooth and free of sharp or abrasive conditions, with 1/8"min. radius. Edges and corners are required to be eased. The finish of the railing must contrast with the wall surface finish by a minimum of 30% and be able to withstand cleaning and disinfection.

diagrams.title: Doors and Door Hardware in Behavioral / Mental Health Hospitals
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
In Behavioral and Mental Health Hospitals, all doors and doorway openings in new construction that will be utilized by patients must meet the following minimum requirements:
  • 32" clear opening width from the door face to the strike stop with the door open at 90 degrees.
  • Hardware:
    General: all hardware shall be mounted with tamper-resistant fasteners.
    Closer: if provided shall be mortised type or surface mounted on the public side of the door.
    Hinges:
    • Shall be designed to minimize points for hanging.
    • Shall be consistent with the level of care required for the patients

    Handles: shall be ligature-resistant (without points where a cord, rope, bedsheet, or other fabric/material can be looped or tied to create sustainable point of attachment that may result in self-harm or loss of life). This was added in the 2022 version.

diagrams.title: Sprinkler Reqs.  - Hospital Clothes Closets
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Where the clothes closet in a patient sleeping room has an area less than 6' and the distance from sprinkler in the room to the projected backwall of the closet does not exceed the distance of the maximum sprinkler spacing distance from a wall (9.5.3.2 2019 or 8.5.3.2 2016), sprinklers may be omitted.

diagrams.title: Glazing in Hospital Renovations (FGI)
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Wire glass in itself is not considered safety glazing. Beginning with the 2006 edition of building codes, traditional wired glass, which did not conform to safety glazing requirements, was no longer exempt from safety glazing standards when used in any hazardous location for all new construction. If wire glass is used, be sure that it also meets the safety glazing requirements of Building Code Section 2406 as well.

diagrams.title: Window Reqs. in Patient Rooms
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Because the natural daylight and its cycle are important for the psychological well-being of patients the code requires windows in patient rooms. The code defines the minimum window size based on the required clear floor area for the room, which is defined elsewhere in the code. The window must be sized to provide a minimum net glazed area of 8% of the required clear floor area for the room. If the window provided is operable, its operation needs to be limited such that a 4" sphere cannot pass through the opening to prevent accidental falls from the window. In new construction the window sill height may not exceed 36" above the floor. In renovation work where meeting the standards is impractical or impossible the jurisdiction having authority may grant approval to deviate from the requirements noted above.

diagrams.title: Doors: Patient Bathing / Toilet Facilities (Hospitals)
diagrams.descriptionHtml: In the Hospital Guidelines, because patient bathroom doors need to enable rescue access without hitting the occupant when opening the door, configurations allowed are as follows: a single out swinging door, two separate doors, a door with emergency rescue hardware, or a non-pocket sliding door. Visual privacy to toilet and bathing rooms that open to public areas or corridors also needs to be provided.

diagrams.title: Doors: Swing & Hardware (Hospitals)
diagrams.descriptionHtml: In the Hospital Guidelines, Except for doors serving non-habitable spaces, doors may not swing into corridors unless provided with an alcove that is deep enough to contain the door swing. Latching lever or push/pull type strike side hardware is required on doors except for some operating room conditions. Operating rooms in a designated suite that do not open to an egress corridor are not required to have latching hardware and may be self-closing with push/pull plates.

diagrams.title: Doors: Types & Openings (Hospitals)
diagrams.descriptionHtml: The Hospital Guidelines allow for two different types of doors, swinging or sliding doors. Where sliding doors are provided they may be manual or automatic providing emergency exiting requirements are not compromised and there are no floor tracks. Emergency breakaway sliding doors prior to breakaway may restrict the minimum corridor width. The minimum door opening size is 44-1/2" wide by 83-1/4" tall for doors to patient rooms and diagnostic and treatment areas. When a swinging door for personnel is provided in addition to a sliding door the swinging door clear width may be reduced to 32".

diagrams.title: Distance of Travel within Group I-2 Sleeping Room
diagrams.descriptionHtml: The maximum exit access travel distance of 50' is allowed in a Group I-2 occupancy sleeping room that is not located in a care suite. The travel distance is measured from any point within the sleeping room to the exit access door of the sleeping room.

diagrams.title: Non-rated Doors in Group I-2 Corridors
diagrams.descriptionHtml: At Group I-2 corridors, non rated doors shall comply with following requirements; solid doors must fit tightly with proper stops; Dutch-style doors require proper edge treatments, latching hardware on both sections, and a mechanism to operate as one unit. To provide for makeup air for exhaust systems, doors may include louvers or a bottom clearance of up to 2/3 inch.

diagrams.title: Group I-2: Direct Access to Corridor
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Habitable rooms in I-2 occupancies such as patient or exam rooms are required to exit via an exit access door directly to a corridor. The code provides for two exceptions to this rule. If the room has an exit door opening directly to the outside at ground level an exit access door leading directly to a corridor is not required. If the room is part of a suite in compliance with section 407.4.4 an exit access door leading directly to a corridor is not required.

children.body: Occupancies in Group I-2 shall comply with the provisions of Sections 407.1 through 407.11 and other applicable provisions of this code.

Corridors in occupancies in Group I-2 shall be continuous to the exits and shall be separated from other areas in accordance with Section 407.3 except spaces conforming to Sections 407.2.1 through 407.2.6.

diagrams.title: Nursing Home Areas Open to Corridors
diagrams.descriptionHtml: In Group I-2, Condition 1 nursing home areas, shared living, meeting, or therapeutic spaces may open directly to corridors if specific safety requirements are met. These include constructing walls and ceilings to corridor standards, ensuring the spaces are not used for sleeping, treatment, hazardous, or incidental uses, and providing automatic fire detection systems. Additionally, corridors in the same smoke compartment must have fire detection or the compartment must have quick response sprinklers, and the layout must maintain clear access to required exits.

diagrams.title: Gift Shops in I-2 Corridors
diagrams.descriptionHtml: In group I-2 occupancies no separation is required between a corridor and a giftshop and its associated storage provided the giftshop is less than 500 sf including storage and the space is constructed as would be required for a corridor.

children.body:
Waiting areas, public-use areas or group meeting spaces constructed as required for corridors shall be permitted to be open to a corridor, only where all of the following criteria are met:
  1. The spaces are not occupied as care recipient's sleeping rooms, treatment rooms, incidental uses in accordance with Section 509, or hazardous uses.
  2. The open space is protected by an automatic fire detection system installed in accordance with Section 907.
  3. The corridors onto which the spaces open, in the same smoke compartment, are protected by an automatic fire detection system installed in accordance with Section 907, or the smoke compartment in which the spaces are located is equipped throughout with quick-response sprinklers in accordance with Section 903.3.2.
  4. The space is arranged so as not to obstruct access to the required exits.

diagrams.title: Hospital Reception Areas or Lobbies
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
Because there will likely be a disproportionate number of disabled people served by a hospital in comparison to other businesses, the hospital guidelines define what needs to be provided and accessed from within hospital lobbies and reception areas. Within the lobby the following need to be provided:
  • Access to information (typically a reception desk with an attendant).
  • A public waiting area.
  • Public toilet room(s).
  • Access to drinking water.
  • Access to public communications services (phone and internet where available).

children.body: Spaces for care providers', supervisory staff, doctors' and nurses' charting, communications and related clerical areas shall be permitted to be open to the corridor, where such spaces are constructed as required for corridors.

Areas wherein psychiatric care recipients who are incapable of self-preservation are housed, or group meeting or multipurpose therapeutic spaces other than incidental uses in accordance with Section 509, under continuous supervision by facility staff, shall be permitted to be open to the corridor, where the following criteria are met:
  1. Each area does not exceed 1,500 square feet (140 m2).
  2. The area is located to permit supervision by the facility staff.
  3. The area is arranged so as not to obstruct any access to the required exits.
  4. The area is equipped with an automatic fire detection system installed in accordance with Section 907.2.
  5. Not more than one such space is permitted in any one smoke compartment.
  6. The walls and ceilings of the space are constructed as required for corridors.
Gift shops and associated storage that are less than 500 square feet (455 m2) in area shall be permitted to be open to the corridor where such spaces are constructed as required for corridors.

diagrams.title: Gift Shops in I-2 Corridors
diagrams.descriptionHtml: In group I-2 occupancies no separation is required between a corridor and a giftshop and its associated storage provided the giftshop is less than 500 sf including storage and the space is constructed as would be required for a corridor.

children.body:
In Group I-2, Condition 1 occupancies, in areas where nursing home residents are housed, shared living spaces, group meeting or multipurpose therapeutic spaces shall be permitted to be open to the corridor, where all of the following criteria are met:
  1. The walls and ceilings of the space are constructed as required for corridors.
  2. The spaces are not occupied as resident sleeping rooms, treatment rooms, incidental uses in accordance with Section 509, or hazardous uses.
  3. The open space is protected by an automatic fire detection system installed in accordance with Section 907.
  4. The corridors onto which the spaces open, in the same smoke compartment, are protected by an automatic fire detection system installed in accordance with Section 907, or the smoke compartment in which the spaces are located is equipped throughout with quick-response sprinklers in accordance with Section 903.3.2.
  5. The space is arranged so as not to obstruct access to the required exits.

diagrams.title: Group I-2 Nursing Homes: Accessiblity
diagrams.descriptionHtml: In Group I-2 nursing homes, Condition 1, facilities must include both Accessible units and Type B units. At least 50 percent, but not fewer than one of each type of dwelling or sleeping unit, must be Accessible units. Exceptions allow water closets and roll-in showers in up to 90 percent of the Accessible units to comply with the alternative provisions in Sections 1110.2.2 and 1110.2.3. In buildings with four or more units intended for residential occupancy, all such units must be designed as Type B units unless a reduced number for Type B units is allowed under Section 1108.7.

diagrams.title: Nursing Home Areas Open to Corridors
diagrams.descriptionHtml: In Group I-2, Condition 1 nursing home areas, shared living, meeting, or therapeutic spaces may open directly to corridors if specific safety requirements are met. These include constructing walls and ceilings to corridor standards, ensuring the spaces are not used for sleeping, treatment, hazardous, or incidental uses, and providing automatic fire detection systems. Additionally, corridors in the same smoke compartment must have fire detection or the compartment must have quick response sprinklers, and the layout must maintain clear access to required exits.

children.body:
